simula.runtime

Class Prototype

  • java.lang.Object
    • simula.runtime.Prototype

  • public class Prototype
extends java.lang.Object
    Prototypes.

    In general, the structure of each block instance is described by a prototype. Each family of block instance has one compiler-generated prototype. Thus, for example, all dynamic instances of the same procedure are described by the prototype for that procedure. The types of block instance which have prototypes are subblocks, prefixed blocks, procedure instances and class objects. Connection blocks have no prototypes.

    This general rule is, however, weaker for four special types of block instance: Array, Accumulator Stack and Text Object. Those data blocks have neither a prototype nor an ordinary driver, but the relevant descriptors are stored within the block instance according to some fixed format definition.

    The design of prototype is such that the central runtime system has quick access to the information required to construct a block instance. Furthermore, during storage collapse, the garbage collector uses the prototype to identify the characteristics of objects to be retained or discarded. The design of the prototype, therefore, is such as to achieve maximum efficiency during both storage allocation and storage collapse.

    The contents of a prototype are not changed during execution.

    Author:
    Øystein Myhre Andersen

    • Field Detail

      • plev

        public int plev
        Prefix level.

        Prefix level is defined in Common Base sect. 2.2.1. Prefix level numbering starts at zero. That is, it is zero for subblocks, procedures and classes without prefixes.

      • npar

        public int npar
        Total number of formal parameters. I.e. including parameters of prefixes.

      • nloc

        public int nloc
        Total number of locally declared quantities.

      • nvirt

        public int nvirt
        Total number of Virtual Match Actions.

      • prefix

        public Prototype[] prefix
        Prefix List.

        The prefix list is only present for classes and prefixed blocks. It is used to hold the prefix chain (the chain of ptotype pointers) defined for each such block instance.

        The prefix chain is terminated by prefix[n] which points back to the prototype entry of the prototype itself.

      • pcheckCode

        public ProgramPoint pcheckCode
        Parameter check code (only for procedures):

        The address of a sequence of code which checks, at runtime, the qualification of reference parameters to formal, virtual or external procedures. For procedures which are not used as formal, virtual or external, there is no parameter check code since all parameter checking can be performed at compile time.

      • declare

        public ProgramPoint declare
        Start address of declaration code. This only apply if the instance have locally declared arrays. If there is no declaration code, declare==statements.

      • statements

        public ProgramPoint statements
        Start address of first executable statement belonging to this block.

      • endpblk

        public ProgramPoint endpblk
        Startaddress of the code which follows the prefixed block.

      • qual

        public Prototype qual
        Pointer to the Prototype of the qualifying class.

      • localClasses

        public boolean localClasses

      • blockLevel

        public int blockLevel
        Block Level.

      • length

        public int length
        Total length of each block instance of this family. (including that of data for all possible prefixes). This includes space for description of each array declared within the object. The array itself is not part of the block instance.
